I have to admit this movie surprised me. It had a lot more drama and heart than I expected, but I shouldn't be surprised considering that it's a Jude Apatow movie. The acting is good, the characters are likable enough, and the pacing is smooth. This was definitely... watchable.It seems Apatow can't decided whether he's making a drama or a comedy, so he just combines them to make well made dramadies. All his films are well made technically, but they're very inconsistent on delivering laughs. And that's very much the case here because "Trainwreck" is one of the most unfunny (yet still watchable) dramadies that I've seen. I think I mildly chuckled no more than three times. It's mostly awkward conversations about sex and female bodily functions. I'm sure there were more varied jokes, but I can't remember and I just watched this only a few hours ago.There's one particular face-hurting scene involving LeBron James, a sports announcer and Matthew Broderick(?) conduction an "intervention" with Bill Header. NO ONE in the theater laughed. Painful.It's not the dreary frustrating slog that Apatow's "Funny People" was, but it falls far short of the entertainment value that "Knocked Up" or "40 Year-Old Virgin" had. This was just a great way to spend the afternoon. I don't really know what to say, honestly. I laughed a ton. The central romance was really sweet. I love all the actors and other talent involved.I think in a lot of ways this movie could seem overly conventional. After all, the main character sleeps around a lot, then ends up flummoxed by the idea of actually finding someone they want to spend time with. The ending involves a big romantic gesture and an inevitable kiss and 'I love you.' There's a wealth of minor characters who are super quirky and funny (Vanessa Bayer, Randall Park, Jon Glaser, Ezra Miller, etc.) but who don't have a ton of depth beyond that.There are two main things that make up for the conventionality of the story. One, a lot of it feels fresher than usual just because there's some nice gender reversal. Amy is an awesomely complex character, funny and witty but pretty narcissistic when it comes down to it. And though it's conventional that the story moves from polyamory to monogamy in a traditional way, Amy never apologizes for her actions, never makes sleeping around sound like a thing she deeply regrets or agrees to stop smoking pot. The other main thing is just that it's super funny. I laughed countless times, and when you're laughing constantly, it's easy to forgive most cliches or predictable endings. It's why the romantic comedy is the genre I'm often the most forgiving of. If I love the stars and the characters are sweet together and I laugh a lot, it's a success in my book.I also got really emotionally invested in the story, though. I could see Amy's father dying from miles away, but it still produced really emotional moments, like, of course, the funeral. I almost teared up when Amy admitted that though her father was often a terribly offensive person, he was her favorite person. And I almost teared up later on, when Kim's son showed Amy his Minecraft drawings, which included a hypothetical guest room for Amy and Aaron, and again when the whole family was hugging. Brie Larson was predictably great as Kim, and I really bought the sister relationship between them. It could've felt like a digression, but it added dimensions to Amy as a character, and in some ways it seemed a little less conventional than the main romantic arc. I especially loved Amy's dislike of her slightly creepy nephew.All in all, like I said, this was a comedy with a writer, director, and cast that I uniformly loved, with consistent laughs and an emotional heart. What more can you really ask for in a romantic comedy?

When a young Amy is instructed that monogamy is unrealistic she really takes it to heart. Flash forward twenty three years and she's landed herself a job at Snuff magazine, a publication whose irreverence and cynicism is matched only by the Cruella Deville-tier inhumanity of its editer; Amy's boss. Things seem to be going well, Amy gets paid to poke a stick at stuffy, conventional 'normals' with her articles by day, and by night is doing what any self-respecting strong, independent career woman in New York (is it New York? Apatow seems to like the idea of the location as a character but Ghostbusters this ain't) would do; she's bonking. She's bonking hot guys, ugly guys, skinny guys, straight guys, gay guys, underage guys, you name it, if it's got a penis (or on three occasions a vagina) she's bonking it.Of course, this state of blissful ignorance can only last so long. This reviewer doesn't think he's giving anything away when he says that monogamy, in the end, turns out to be best all around after all, but there's no reason the movie had to be so heavy-handed in getting us there. Serious illness, family tragedy, drug abuse and lots of soul searching detract from what could have been a fun couple of hours, as Schumer's writing for herself and the stellar cast of cameo stars is very nearly buried under an avalanche of out-of-place feeling conservative family value and melodrama.One feels that Schumer wandered onto the set in the middle of shooting one of her (much funnier and less taxing) skits, and resigned herself to the trade-off she'd have to make on her character if she wanted to stay on the big screen until the end. When she goes, in the space of 48 hours, from a bar crawling, nymphomaniac, libertine stoner to a jealous girlfriend at a ballgame pouring scorn on the cheerleaders for their 'ways' it makes you wonder how brutal the studio enforced rewrite must have been.The movie really is saved, for some of us at least, by the guest appearances. This reviewer owns up to being a big time pro-wrestling fan and people, let me tell you right now, you can see John Cena in this movie. I mean, the champ is all there, and his Schumer dialogue and character (no idea how the 500+ make a wish foundation superstar agreed to it all) are worth the price of entry five times over.Likewise, one must assume, for basketball fans with Lebron James; and so it goes. If the cameos haven't whetted your appetite, you've seen and don't care for Schumer's comedy and you really can't stand another turn on the Hollywood life-affirming 'don't be different' merry-go-round, you'll want to give this a miss. Otherwise, ignore the strained plot, enjoy the (sometimes inspired) humour, and you might be able to get away with cashing it in as your chick-flick for the month, so you can drag the girlfriend along to Mission Impossible: Rogue Nation with a clean conscience.3/5

Funny at times, but lacking in others, this film doesn't quite have enough humour for the solid 2 hour run time, and isn't compelling enough with its drama to justify its length either. Amy Schumer is good in the lead, but many of the characters around her are so un-life like that it drags down the drama and the film struggles to really delve into the character of Amy and address her flaws as a character. She is afterall, supposed to be a trainwreck...
Very pleasantly surprised, sometimes she can be over the top but this was good stuff, John Cena sex scene was worth the price of admission, funny as!!!
funniest movie of the years, great Chemistry of Amy schumer and bill hader
Laughed out loud more times than I am proud of. Best movie since "There's something about Mary." Not a big fan of basket ball, but other wise a perfect movie. Please keep making movies Amy.

It's not totally devoid of laughs, but the humor is so sparse (and there are so many awkward misfires) that overall it doesn't render as a funny or even enjoyable experience. Instead, it feels like an overlong and overdone production, wrought with clich�s and offering little of substance. At times it felt like being at a stand-up show where most of the jokes fell flat, only there was no one there to heckle the offenders off the stage; it was just genuinely uncomfortable.The dramatic moments also seem out of place here, and it's hard to take them seriously despite Schumer's commitment. Many scenes felt like they were written around pre-orchestrated stand-up material, as though the scenario was nothing more than a vehicle for a joke, rather than the joke servicing the scene. Therein lies the problem. Yes, it may be funny at times and Schumer as a stand-up comic is generally great, but without a strong plot acting as a backbone, the film falls apart.Also, the pacing was just horrible and as a result the film draggggggs. At two hours long, there is so much here that could have been cut.Like all of it, for example.

I thought the end scene with Amy doing her cheerleader routine was a perfect summary. She actually was trying hard to look hot, then clearly flubbed some moves to appear goofy and earnest.

Wrecking it for all rom-coms to follow, this whipsmart Train keeps chugging along thanks to honest, intelligent and hilarious look at monogamy come-lately. Characterizing Schumer as just a bawdy sketch comedienne gives one of the industry's sharpest minds short shrift. She kills it in long form too which is how superstars get made. An extension of her frank observations on Comedy Central's Inside Amy Schumer, this filmic misadventure also marks director Judd Apatow's best work since Knocked Up. This film doesn't just take a hard look at commitment phobia, it gives amazingly fresh and doubled-over laughingly funny insight into modern dating and romance. In this R-rated comedy, a commitment-phobic career woman (Schumer) who never thought that monogamy was possible faces her fears when she meets a good guy (Hader). Not only does Schumer's screenplay present a unique warts 'n' all romantic comedy, she emerges as one of the best comedic actresses working in film today. Lebron James nearly derails her train a few times with a fantastically funny supporting turn, but there's no denying this comedienne's R-rated charm. Sure, her big screen starring debut falls into formula a bit but rom-coms dictate a good deal of connecting the dots or else it becomes relationship tragedy. Brilliant and beautiful, her Trainwreck is an absolute for adult moviegoers who appreciate a dirty joke.Bottom line: N'Yuk-ed Up
A movie you can take a date and her sister to.

Monogamy isn't realistic?Rating: R (for strong sexual content, nudity, language and some drug use)Genre: ComedyDirected By: Judd ApatowRun : 125 minutesStars: Amy Schumer, Bill Hader, Brie Larson Colin QuinnHave you ever answered your phone the morning after the night you slept over at the guy's house you met for the first time and hoped that his butt mis-dialed you!!! yeh...I hear you... I guess we can relate to this at least once in our life time.Amy Schumer whose motto I assume is like mine 'Work Hard Party harder' does exactly that when her dad drummed into her young head 'Monogamy isn't realistic?' images (3)The opening scene sets the president for what we were in store for, in which her up to no good dad (Colin Quinn) explains to his little girls, Amy and her sister Kim (Brie Larson) just why he's getting divorced from their mum - 'Your doll. you love your doll but what if it was the only doll you were allowed to play with for the rest of your lives? "What about a doll you play with only one day and never see again?" he asks. The girls think that sounds a great idea and in no time he has the tots happily chanting "Monogamy isn't realistic!"Trainwreck has to be one of the funniest romantic movie I have seen in a very long time. refreshing look at how women look at their role when it comes to dating. Reminded me a bit of Bridget Jones character, frumpy, clumsy, career women, average looking. but in this case not committed to love at all. A career women behaving badly is all I'm saying.It is worth a visit to the cinema, to sit back and enjoy some real tongue in cheek banter . A chic flick that will have you wetting your knickers. Look out for some celebrity appearances .images (5)Ms Safirah IraniTwitter@Safirah63

Honestly I wanted to really love this film after the positive word of mouth, unfortunately like Knocked Up I just am not fussed about it. Don't get me wrong this is very much a likeable comedy with some genuine funny laughs see John Cena in the cinema.The cast all give likeable performances from Amy Schumer to Ezra Miller's ADHD riddled intern, the performances are spot on even Tilda Swinton with her very wonky accent is a joy in this film.So what's the story the opening scene sees Colin Quinn drill into his daughters that monogamy isn't realistic, which results in 23 years later Amy Schumer's Amy having meaningless sex frequently. She's dating John Cena but isn't into him other than for sex. Meanwhile her sister played by the stunning Brie Larsen is married to Tom and raised his son who likes to call her mother and is genuinely quite odd. Working for a trashy magazine Amy dreams of being a proper writer rather than writing for a magazine which goes with pieces like "Am I gay or are you just boring". She is assigned to do a piece on Bill Hader's Sports surgeon sparks fly and relationship is formed will Amy see it through and find love?Trainwreck is amusing and entertaining in parts with genuine laugh out loud moments then it's such a shame that the film is so perfunctory, the plot is predictable you pretty much know how the characters are going to end up and as such it offers nothing fresh in the romcom genre.
Very funny and entertaining. Amy will get more starring roles soon.

This is a pretty good comedy. I was not disappointed. The story was good. The chemistry between Amy Schumer and her romantic interest; played by Bill Hader, is good. Hader seems to be a very capable actor. Up to now he has mostly played principally comedic roles. He is in a comedy here; but his role is more of a straight man to Amy Schumer's comedic role.The film is rated R. Schumer is known for her mainly bawdy comedy. She talks a lot about sexual matters, from a female point-of-view. I like her. She is funny. The are a few sex scenes. I was a little surprised to find that Schumer did not choose to show any nudity involving herself. Although, some of the men are seen mostly naked, from behind.Some scenes worked better than others, but the movie as a whole, worked for me. There was one odd, scene toward the end, featuring a handful of celebrity cameos. It did not work very well. Chris Evert (former prof tennis star) was present. I did not recognize her at first. She is not aging very well.It was an OK trip to the flics.

When Amy (Amy Schumer) and Kim (Brie Larson) were little kids, their father took them aside and explained that he was leaving their mother because "monogamy isn't realistic", a phrase that is apparently his mantra. Grown-up Amy obviously took the lesson to heart (unlike her happily-married younger sister), as she seems to sleep with any guy who shows the least bit of interest, and even some who don't.The big joke of "Trainwreck" is hey, check out this chick being proud of sleeping around and not wanting emotional attachments and basically acting like A GUY. And all the guys she sleeps with are like "hey, why don't you spend the night?" but she never does and that's funny because ROLE REVERSAL, y'all! As lame of a premise as this is, some of this stuff is actually pretty funny, though other stuff not so much. Fortunately, the ratio of hits to misses is high enough to have kept me fairly amused throughout the movie's slutty first act. Before I continue, I feel compelled to point out that it's possible for one to eschew monogamy without necessarily being promiscuous. Even if one never (ahem) "dates" the same person more than once, an anti-monogamy stance does not actually require one to sleep with every willing person who happens to cross one's path. End of vocabulary lesson.Amy works for a trashy magazine and reports to a very bitchy editor named Dianna (Tilda Swinton) whose complete lack of compassion for her underlings makes for some of the movie's funniest scenes. [I am notoriously bad at recognizing faces, but even looking at side-by-side photos of normal, short-haired, makeup-free Swinton and her character in this movie, I cannot believe they are the same person.]For reasons that don't quite make sense, Dianna assigns sports-hating Amy to write a piece about sports-injury-doctor-to-the-pros Aaron Conners (Bill Hader), who just happens to be besties with LeBron James. As movie predictability would have it, Amy ends up falling for nice-guy Aaron (also active in Doctors without Borders, don't you know), so naturally she feels compelled to try to sabotage their fledgling relationship.Full disclosure: The main reason I saw this movie is I'm a LeBron James fan, as all followers of the NBA should be, unless of course they're jealous, irrational haters. LeBron review: Funny and natural (no doubt helped by the fact that he's playing himself). Side note: How many movies have YOU been in lately, Steph Curry?I've heard a lot of "Trainwreck" bashing lately, the gist of which is "I thought it was supposed to be SO good, but it wasn't THAT good", including from my dental hygienist as she scraped plaque off my teeth, leaving me unable to respond. Had I remembered, when she'd finished, I would have said this: "High expectations will do you in every time." Instead I simply spat. "Trainwreck" is an Amy Schumer vehicle, a light summer rom-com that is no doubt better than "Vacation" and "Pixels", but even the best summer rom-com is still just a summer rom-com. Here's a little tip for everyone seeing this movie's 86% Tomatometer score and expecting it to be 2015's "When Harry Met Sally": movies that are released in the middle of the summer are graded on a curve. "Trainwreck" definitely exceeded my appropriately-low-to-moderate expectations, though it gets a bit draggy at the end and should have been at least fifteen minutes shorter. In a movie like this, we all know where it's going almost from the start and at some point the whole audience is like "just get there already!", amirite?On the plus side, the theater was nicely air conditioned, but not so frigid as to require a wrap. And, of course, LeBron's in it.

Terrible. It pains me to say that about a Judd Apatow film. Every single character annoyed me, except the father who was the only decent actor with some decent jokes. Feminism shmemenism. I don't need a romantic comedy to defend me. There are better ways to express feminism and it doesn't include fucking every dude and saying things like "mom was fuckble", are you serious?! It sucks! Romantic sex comedies these day don't seem to live up to what they used to be, in fact I don't think I have seen a decent one in ages and don't often go to see them!And did not have high hopes where this one was concerned as most trailers for these films look good but use all the decent laughs for the Trailer but with good word of mouth I approached this film with a little faith and boy did I enjoy it.It has a great story, great characters and one of the best Usual Suspects Jokes that had me in fits!There is also a great little cameo from one magical boy that is so strange I'm surprised they don't tern it into a film!That said though the film feels grounded in reality at times it dose spill into unreal over the top comedy hat though funny dose not fit the overall movie but other than that this is a a great laugh and one I know will watch many times in the future.

Most romantic comedies suck. Even the one with Gerard Butler after his 300 success where he tries to be a 'mans man' as much as possible. But this one was actually funny. Witty, sharp, and almost locker-room-like in it's humor. Also not too sappy.

Great cameos aside (my stand out is the wrestler John Cena amongst many sports and movie stars), this is an above average adult comedy with an eye on inverting rom-com conventions for a more realistic take on the genre, and succeeds but only to an extent. The sometimes sketchy script is smart, funny and chock full of cultural references, proving Amy Schumer to be a very competent comedian who can also summon up some reasonable acting skills too when need be. However, like most Apatow comedies, it does meanders a bit, though not unjustifiably so in this case, and fails on the final hurdle in its non-conformity to genre expectations. Maybe what we need in the end is another injection of realism instead of the overly cute happy ending?
Fun movie. Lots of cameos. Amy Schumer delivers a believable performance. Good stuff.
Not bad, but more rom than com unfortunately.

Funny when it needed to be, soulful, surprisingly deep and well worth your time.
Lots of spoofs. Very funny from women's point of view. Nice if unusual and often funny romance with misunderstandings and discoveries along the way.

* Amy Schumer was very believable in the leading role. She manages to hit every comedic note, while still providing the level of emotion required for the story. * Bill Hader's performance was a bit of a throw away, but passable for the role required. * Lebron James & John Cena's cameos were my personal favourite parts of the film. While it isn't as anti-romantic comedy as it desires to be, still falling into a trope here and there, it is quite funny and engaging featuring a surprisingly emotional schumer, an always great Bill Hader, and......a weirdly funny Lebron James (Which, as a Grizzlies fan, makes me gag to say)

All things considered, with every pun intended, this film could have easily been a "Trainwreck," due to the fact that nobody has seen Amy Schumer leave her comfort zone as far as creating a feature film goes. I can say with certainty, that "Trainwreck" is one of my favourite films of 2015. Not only is it one of Judd Apatow's best films to date, but the dialogue and events that played out throughout this film felt so natural. As a reporter (Schumer) is hired to write a new article on a doctor (Bill Hader) who performs surgeries on major sports icons, she finds herself falling in love, which is something she never intended. As stale as that sounds, it is the freshest take on this type of story that I have seen in the last few years. I was laughing hysterically throughout this picture, and that is due to the great writing, tremendous acting, and a slow paced editing style that always adds that next level to Apatow's best works. "Trainwreck" does exactly what it sets out to do, and for that reason I can find no faults in this film. The one big fault that this film does suffer from however, like every Apatow film, it is just a tad too long. I am normally not a fan of this type of comedy, but it is so quick that I was laughing throughout almost every scene, and I was in tears on multiple occasions. Yes, a Judd Apatow comedy made me tear up... This film really is something special to the genre. It may just be me, but I believe this film is fantastic. "Trainwreck" was a huge surprise for me and I highly recommend it.
it's funny and all the jokes are great. The story is interesting to follow.

Amy Schumer kills it. Trainwreck is as hilariously vulgar and surprisingly likable as seeing Superbad or Knocked-Up for the first time. It's certainly not a movie for everyone, but does a fantastic job bringing a lot of hard-hitting jokes to the otherwise formulaic story-arc. The only thing that was a little disappointing was having Bill Hader playing the straight man. I felt like his comedic range was an untapped opportunity.
Critics like it, probably because it feels real. But I didn't care for it.

A movie about a genuinely horrible, mean and spiteful person that throughout the entire movie you're conditioned to like less and less. So much so that by the time it comes to the third act and she learns her valuable lesson, you struggle to give a damn and finish the film still really disliking her and feeling genuinely sorry for the poor guy who's ended up with her. Painfully long and self indulgent scenes with very little pay off, peppered with humour so subtle that you'll genuinely feel surprised to hear yourself snort... twice... three times, tops!
funny and fresh and sweet and touching.

Quintessential Judd Apatow: Start out with a bang, get settled, then meander through a heart-felt third act. Amy Schumer, as writer and star, has the bustling talent to transcend such schlocky cliches but tries, at times successfully, to break out from within these lines. As far as romantic comedies go, this is a note above the rest.

Trainwreck was funny. It is very clear Amy Schumer has a bright career as a movie actor in front of her to compliment her already stellar comedy show. She wrote this script and Judd Apatow directed it. Now, she's famous for her stand-up comedy and short skits on TV, and it's a bit obvious she's lacking in the longer script territory. Sure the movie follows almost every rom-com trope to a T, but it's the dialogue and jokes which move you along that keep you interested. First off, John Cena absolutely steals the show with his 5 or so minutes of screen time over a handful of scenes. He had me on the floor with his super bulked up body builder physique nice guy who might be secretly gay routine. The bedroom scene was pure instant classic.Secondly, while it was fun to see LeBron James in on the act, I didn't feel as convinced about his acting. Maybe that's because Cena actually puts on a show as a wrestler while LeBron isn't on a basketball court.Tilda Swinton was almost unrecognizable, as she usually is, and played the evil editor as outlandishly as she could. Brie Larson, as beautiful as ever, knocked the grown-up sister role out of the park. Even Daniel Radcliff and Marissa Tomei made a brief cameo in a movie about dog walking I'd actually like to see for the absurdity of it.However, it is so nice to see Bill Hader continue to branch out of his zany roles he once had at SNL to play somewhat of a straight character and still deliver on his comedic timing. He's one of my favorites. His chops and Amy's ridiculousness both with degrading physical humor and word humor make them a great pair.But it all falls back into the rom-com category. Nothing you didn't see coming. Nothing frivolous about the plot other than it's a woman drinking and smoking and sleeping around rather than a man. That's not supposed to make this feel new-age or conquering of the norm. I'd like to see Schumer continue to write movies and get better at it. It was sharp, witty and relatable, and that's a tip of the hat to Apatow on his direction. It makes the comedy pure.
I really enjoyed the story and how the movie played out. Many times the whole theater was laughing. I saw this movie at least 3 times now.
I love Amy Schumer but not this movie. It was cute but way too sexualized. The script wasn't that strong but there was a story nothing less. Just not a great one.
A laugh out loud comedy that brings tears to your eyes, both from its hilarious moments and its touching ones. Smartly written, this movie makes the conventional rom-com feel inventive and fresh.

I wanted to like this and while I did find some parts funny, the film overall is generic and nothing I haven't seen before. It's just another raunchy romantic comedy with awkward comedy to be funny but instead is just dead air to makes the audience uncomfortable. I usually am ok with dirty raunchy comedies but when I know the joke is coming from a mile away it makes it boring. The beat by beat humor is nothing great and does every check on the romantic comedy checklist. Now not saying anybody was bad in the film I just think as a story or character film it's kind of boring. I tried really hard to enjoy this movie, I really did. But between the awkward dead air add libed comedy it really felt like there was dead space and didn't make the film enjoyable it almost was just slaughtering the pace of the movie. This movie was sorely unimpressive and sadly enough it's directed by Judd Apatow and I usually love his heartfelt comedies but this was just kind of mediocre. If anything I'd rather recommend the funnier Bridesmaids that is just like Trainwreck but way more entertianing and consistant.

There's little doubt that Schumer is a star in the making with a point of view and plenty to say. But as a star vehicle, Trainwreck could have done with going off the rails a little more to compliment her talent.

Trainwreck is a funny affair and has its moments but ultimately ends up being like any other rom com. The first half is the best part about the film and also Bill Hader's relationship with Lebron James. Overall Trainwreck is a good time, but isn't all that it was cracked up to be.
Hilarious with some depth. Only complaint is the running time.

Genuinely hilarious.

Parents, the masterminds behind our first steps, our first experiences and our whole life of learning, the people responsible of shaping who we are, but also the one to blame if we end up been a mess.This is the simple plot of the film "Trainwreck" directed by Judd Apatow the film focus on the little girl that been influenced by her father Gordon Townsend (Colin Quinn) with the message of monogamy isn't realistic. Gordon is an alcoholic and promiscuous guy who spent his last days at a nursing home.Amy (Amy Schumer) a writer for a men's magazine is the mirror of her father, the resonance of the monogamy of dad's message, makes her a girl without commitments, afraid of the future with somebody, but also an alcoholic. You see the opposite attitude in Amy's sister Kim (Brie Larson) a settled woman, with a husband and a step kid living the typical family life. The film doesn't focus on that parallel, but just highlight moments with comedic situations, which ease the drama of that, dismembered family. Mom is no longer with them and the two girls live the pain of taking care of their dad and coping with his behavior, specially for Amy who get along with him, not so for Kim.The conflict in Trainwreck is when Amy is assigned to write a piece about a sport surgeon Aaron Conners (Bill Hader). Her boss Dianna (Tilda Swinton) is a cheeky British woman who projects her feelings about men and their lifestyle in the magazine. She is ruthless and insensitive, but is the boss. After Amy begged Diana to no give her this story, she have to accept, just with the promise of a promotion.Amy spent several occasions watching him work and do his job. Unfortunately for Amy, Aaron fell in love with her and feel attached to this messy woman. The conflict begins and the relationship goes deeper. She has to confront all her fears and is not easy.Judd Apatow develops a story written by Schumer into a funny story of this conflicted woman. The film presents the characters as caricatures of the typical life in NYC, with the vignettes of the urban city. The guys who date Amy are those stereotypes, including Steven (John Cena) a sensitive body builder, who enjoys artsy movies, walks in the park to name a few. My problem with "Trainwreck" is the story and the dialogues. I can swear that Amy talks in the same voice of Annie Walker (Kristin Wiig) in Bridesmaid, in fact are kind of the same character. Sometimes I feel that I seen this characters in other films, but also seems that the conflict in "Trainwreck" never reach its peaks, but neither the resolutions. Don't get me wrong some jokes are funny, other ones borderline into vulgar.The movie is entertaining and fun, Amy Schumer and Bill Hader are great together.

It's Amy Schumer, so you can be pretty sure it'll be funny and smart, and yet as funny as this was I expected just a little bit more from her. She's hilarious, Bill Hader is charming and terrific, Colin Quinn never quite pulls off the lovability we're supposed to feel for him, though he is funny, and even LeBron James is great. Not for the faint of heart. It's a hard R for a reason.

As a fan of 'Inside Amy Schumer', I knew what to expect from this film - and indeed if you know Schumer's style of comedy, the main surprise from this film is that is actually is quite a conventional rom-com at heart. Schumer's hilarious persona of an average girl who likes to talk about sex in a frank and funny way is definitely something we've not seen since 'Bridesmaids'. Judd Apatow is sometimes criticized for his laddish bromantic comedies, but his championing of Lena Dunham, Melissa McCarthy, Kristen Wiig and now Amy Schumer really should earn him major feminist kudos! Schumer is more amiable, less crude than Melissa McCarthy's comedic persona; she is more of what it means to be a sexually active female in the 21st century - in fairly graphic detail at times! In this film she plays another version of this persona as Amy, a free wheeling modern girl with a good job at a pretty awful men's magazine and a happy and varied sex life with a string of men. As a child, her father had instilled in her that 'monogamy isn't realistic' in a very funny opening flashback scene. We meet her as she half heartedly dates a rather odd body builder with gay tendencies. Soon her boss at the magazine - an almost unrecognisable Tilda Swinton - sends her to interview Aaron (Bill Hader), rather dorky orthopedic surgeon to lots of famous athletes. His best friend is basketball star LeBron James, who has a really nice line in dry wit as an actor. Of course, Amy knows nothing about sports, but she pretty much talks him into bed straight away, expecting her usual one night stand. However, they unexpectedly start to build a relationship after Hader pursues her, but can Amy overcome her reticence about commitment?The first half of the film is really nicely subversive. Sex is portrayed in a way only 'Bridemaids' has done in the past. Kind of awkward, not at all movie soft-focus, strings and perfections. Also very much from a female perspective - which is still incredibly rare. Amy's bodybuilder boyfriend is a refreshingly hilarious narcissist, and I loved the very funny scene which was in the trailer of Amy and her friend's shock over Hader ringing her after their hook-up. Where the film turns a little formulaic is in the inevitable change in Amy. Her father is ill, she is arguing with her sister over his care, she realizes she does love doctor Aaron and ends up changing to please him. It is just a little bit neat and conventional. I'm not sure if Amy Schumer's message is we all just need to meet the right man to settle down with, but it kind of is the film's. Her commitment free sex life is shown as rather bogus and when she tries to return to a casual hook up with a co-worker, it goes disastrously wrong. See kids, it is true love that works! Still there is an awful lot of very funny material along the way. The appearance of those sports stars might have more meaning to a US audience - I know LeBron James' name and great to see Chris Evert in there - and with a rude line too! Didn't know if some of the others were real stars or just actors. However, James was a lot of fun. I especially liked the scene where he and Bill Hader play basketball and talk. James' hilariously superior height, strength and skill aren't commented on, it's just background for their conversation as Hader utterly fails to gain an inch.Schumer - who also wrote the script - does a pretty decent job of also putting a fair bit of emotion into the father/daughters scenes too. I believe Schumer's own father has MS so I guess there are plenty of autobiographical elements. All of the performances are good. Special mention to Tilda Swinton for having an absolute ball as a fake tan fashionista bitch. Apparently Apatow and Schumer let her have free rein to be as outrageous looking as she wanted! Has Tilda Swinton ever been funny before?The film is not without flaws; Doctor Aaron is far too perfect to still be single, the ending involving cheerleaders is no where near as funny as Schumer's 'Milk, Milk, Lemonade' sketch on her TV show (although also not as rude!) and it is a bit sentimental at times. Her TV show is sharper and more acerbic, while this big screen adventure is less threatening and more mainstream. However, I enjoyed it a lot, very funny film.
Schumer and Apatow flip the traditional rom-com roles and it works beautifully.
It was surprisingly 3 dimensional; don't take anyone you will be embarrassed by sex scenes around, because there is that. And its crude. But it has a good heart. No regrets,
John Cena and LeBron James were the funniest parts!
Excellent film; What a story! Worth the price of admission!

If you're a big Amy Schumer fan, you will be thrilled with this film. If not, you will see someone try to be "edgy" by adding a lot of sexual references and whining to get by. There is nothing special or engrossing about the plot or characters, it's just Amy going through skits intertwined by a generic Rom-Com plot.
Started well, took a dive about an hour in when it went serious. Ended with a good old face plant to lift the mood.

A hard-drinking, hard-partying woman meets a relationship-eligible sports doctor.On a bit-by-bit basis, this comedy is pretty solid - not great comedic bits by any means, but mildly humorous. The best comic talent in the film is actually not Bill Hader or Amy Schumer but LeBron James, who is simply hilarious as Aaron's best friend.The problem with this film is the separation between its goals and what it accomplishes. Politically, Schumer and Apatow are part of modern feminism's movement against slut-shaming and female sexual empowerment, and it's clear that Amy (the character Schumer plays) represents this modern feminist. Yet because it's a romantic comedy through and through, reproducing all the cliches of that genre, Trainwreck forces Amy to change, to return to the tropes that marked women without the lessons of modern feminism. It's true that she never apologizes for her behavior, and the script never asks her to, but the recognition of her need to change indicates that the film's actual political position falls well short of its goals.Overall, while it's a decent comedy, Trainwreck's political aspirations fall short of its reality.
A "rom-com" that has a little bit for everyone.

When LeBron James is almost the best actor in a movie (thank you Tilda Swinton and Ezra Miller ) you know it sucks and this one sucks big time . Comedy Central Amy funny - Trainwreck Amy not so much. Hader is miscast. Nominate the hyper-hokey ending on the basketball court as the most cringe-worthy moment on film this year just ahead of the ending of the Streep movie. An early favorite as worst movie of 2015. (8-15-15)

I not normally a fan of Amy Schumer but this is great fun with the usual Apatow schlub role reversed. Bill Hader is good and makes the most of the straight man role. Amy explores the sandwich generation and has a vulgar sense of humour that works in very well in this film.

Shumer, Hader, and James are funny enough in this hit or miss comedy, (James was the highlight) but the problem is the story that tries to tie everything together. For such a generic plot, the movie is bloated and needlessly convoluted with analogy. I would have rather watched the dog walker movie with Radcliffe and Tomei for two hours.

Super fresh funny and outright hilarious. Amy plays herself as a singleton tainted by settling down after her dads words as a child so she becomes a trainwreck, drinking and sleeping with a lot of men. This is totally original and well worth a watch

I can't believe the hype surrounding this film. For a change, it is good seeing the women in the hit it and quit it role. That and Tilda Swinton was the only other positives and with most Judd Apatow films, it was about 30 minutes too long.

I will admit that I went to this film just to see Schumer. I was expecting over the top smutty sex and biting satire. What we got though was a funny, witty, touching, sentimental movie with some terrific performances...including, of all people, Lebron James. There's some really good material in this. And Bill Hader as her love interest is adorable. Yes, the ending is corny but after the bite of the rest of the movie, this sweet sappy ending is a good balance. I was very pleasantly surprised. I give it 4 good stars.

For those unfamiliar with Amy Schumer, beware, you are about to be. In TRAINWRECK the rising star of US comedy makes her entrance into silver screen stardom with a bang. First and foremost this movie is something different. Instead of having a fun-loving and unattached bachelor find the woman who makes him want to change it is ... basically a fun-loving and unattached bachelorette who finds a man that makes her want to change. In essence it is a role reversal version of the classic cheesy Rom Coms of the 90s and 00s.Some might not be comfortable with this movies take on alcohol, drugs and female promiscuity...but this is the world we live in. The fact that this sort of lifestyle has always been accepted as long as it was being enjoyed by a man is kind of the point of this movie. Deal with it... or don't go see this movie, up to you.While Bill Hader does his part as the grounded and "normal" character he is arguably overshadowed by both his co-star, Mrs Schumer and in the role of his advice giving BFF...Lebron James. Yes the NBA player!James features in what was apparently supposed to be merely a cameo but organically grew into a substantial supporting role. He blends good chemistry with Hader along with self-aware star power and jokes about himself. While this movie is mostly about Schumer, James is definitely the second biggest revelation. The script and cast are great, the jokes land and thought the story does have its fair share of clich�s it is actually moving at times.

Amy Schumer plays Amy, a promiscuous woman who sleeps with men willy nilly and leaves before the sun rises, she is not one for commitment, until she is on assignment for the scrag rag she works for interviewing Aaron, a sport doctor to the rich and famous. Sparks fly and it terrifies her. This is Apatow's best film since Knocked Up in my opinion, there is plenty of rude, crude humour and some very hilarious moments. Schumer in her debut film role is great and Hader is fun as Aaron, I really like Bill Hader and it is good to see him getting a leading man role. Some good supporting characters, John Cena kills it in his limited time as the emotional beefcake lover. As usual, Apatow's films go way too long and there are some quiet moments, film could have survived at a good 90-100 minutes.
pretty funny movie and enjoyable movie

"Let me put my protein in you, yeah...".The fairly speedy rise of 'Amy Schumer' is interesting and its all the more confirmation that the women are dominating top comedies with - 'Amy Schumer' joining: Melissa McCarthy', 'Tina Fey' and 'Amy Poehler'. Having never seen 'Inside Amy Schumer' (sorry) I have to say this has made me take an interest. Even more so given director 'Judd Apatow' generally (or should I say ever) doesn't direct other's work. that alone is enough to take notice (in the short time I was aware of this film). It's an evident style that seems to gel with Amy's writing - and joins the rare 'good comedies over 2hrs group'.Yep it's over 2hr. It's also joyfully (to me) an anti-rom-com. Replacing atypical clich�s in both genders and making them feel real. The film starts where the trailer starts with a young 'Amy' (Amy Schumer) and sister 'Kim' (Brie Larson) are being told by their dad that Monogamy is bad - where it slides off 'Kim' 'Amy' clearly takes it to heart. Where we get guy after guy being rejected by 'Amy'. It's not as simple as "look the women is the one with commitment problems isn't that different!". It smartly doesn't shame 'Amy' either (probably due to the writer) there is a tenancy to go down that path to show some sort of growth. But people don't grow that quickly an she's largely the same person by the end. It could be described as crass - which is usually given as a negative connotation. But it's not as simply as gross stuff that a lesser comedy would do (look at literally anything Adam Sandler has ever written). It's inter-spaced with absurd remarks and Amy's slightly twisted look on people. Actively insulting her sisters kid in-front of her or total confusion over 'Aaron' calling her. There are also some nice little cameos in 'Daniel Radcliffe' and 'Marisa Tomei' is a very strange film The Dog Walker. Aaron's best friend is 'LeBron James' and 'Amy' early on dates someone played by 'John Cena' both of which do a fantastic job and display some great comedic timing.It does end a little flat for me with a bit romantic gesture that isn't entirely out of the realms of possibility given connections. But it still seems a little off. it also tales off on the comedy and focuses more on 'Amy' and Aaron's life and feelings.'Trainwreck' is over 2 hours long and good, I'll say it again over 2 hours long and good. That's not just rare it's unheard off. The writing is sharp and full of fairly biting comments from fun-filled 'Amy'. It's a film where the characters stay who they are, there's no huge realisation and massive change of actions. It all comes down to 'Amy' and 'Aaron' being ok with who each other is and that's real life.

I really wanted to like this, and I heard many many good things. Surprise to me then that there was something really off about it, and I think for me it's all down to Amy Schumer's character and that a lot of the humour was really unfunny. Amy in the movie is basically an arsehole (prolific liar, insensitive and lazy) whose only redeeming feature is perhaps her love for her father, which is so underused it hardly makes a difference. All this could still have been overcome if I believed she was actually invested in her chosen life - "enjoying it" as the blurb says - but she simply comes across as tired and unconvincing, and more of an arsehole. The comic sketches also often run too long, stretching it past funny, and a lot of the other humour is just mean or sad, especially when it came to her step-nephew. The trailer shows parts of scenes that were obviously cut from the final feature. I walked out after an hour. It's has nothing of the characterisation and careful balance of drama and levity in Bridesmaids (as the promos keep telling you).
meh...wait for it on dvd or cable.

I tried to like this movie, I really did, but everything from the lead who looks like a grown up Cabbage Patch Kid, to the horribly written dialog, to the trying too hard to be funny instead (kinda like Amy). It all ended up being a hot mess that annoyed me more than entertained me.
Loved it, laughed the whole time.

Judd Apatow's funniest film in years, backhanded compliment though that be. Amongst the laughs, you never quite forget that the two leads are comedians not actors, but they both have a sense of what works for them. The supporting cast may be the real highlight; Tilda Swinton and Ezra Miller are as great as you expect, whereas LeBron James and especially John Cena are far better than either of them have the right to be. There are a few star cameos that smack of casting around finding something for one's mates to do, but nothing unforgiveable. What does stop the film dead in its tracks more than once is its uncertainty with the conventions and clich�s of romantic comedy; it can't quite decide whether it's bringing up certain tropes to poke fun at or to acknowledge a begrudging truth. Add an ending that's a little too uncomfortable from the perspective of gender politics, even when you know Schumer wrote it, and you're left with something that tries damn hard to let the laughs carry it through and comes damn close - but not quite close enough.

Synopopsis: Free spirit and constantly under the influence girl meets kind-hearted boy. Boy accepts her for who she is while she treats him like dirt and stays emotional distant and mentally ierractic. Boy finally sticks up for himself. Girl flees but comes back reformed, twists herself into the image of what she once hated and lives happily ever after. Wait what? Yup, that's what I thought after watching a disjointed performance in a disjointed movie studded with cameos and lots of bare male butts.
There is a sense of realism that abounds, but it is also disjointed, and the laughs are inconsistent.
This is a VERY funny movie, filled with lots of BIG laughs. Amy is really a fine actress, and everyone in the film delivers. Don't miss this movie.

Amy Schumer is a trainwreck in this boring, predictable rom com. From the reviews I thought it would be fantastic. Boy was that a letdown. The plot's been done a million times (999,998 of them better) and the predictable turnaround/redemption at the end was absolutely not believable or satisfying. This move was great- right up there with Bridesmaids and the Judd Apatow comedy movies. Loved it. I didn't really know about the genius that is Amy Schumer until this movie came out. Really great, funny movie with a lot of wit and charm as well. LeBron James and John Cena taking their turn at acting turned out surprisingly well. LeBron > John Cena. I totally did not know it was Tilda Swinton as Amy's British (hilarious!) boss at the magazine. Wonderful supporting cast, they really pulled out all the stops with the cameos, and the surprise dance toward the end. (NO SPOLIERS, I promise). I would surely recommend this movie to any young woman, but also to anyone looking for a good laugh.

"Trainwreck" is one of the best romantic comedies I'ven seen in years. I went to this movie without any expectations and the movie started to make me happy from the get go. It made me laugh so hard I cried. The film starts off extremely strong with some hard-edged humor. About 2/3 of the way through the film it loses some steam though - still, it didn't really matter because the whole movie switches to a more emotional (I would even go so far and say serious) perspective. "Trainwreck" is an extremely raunchy, yet heartwarming rom-com. There are a number of laughs, probably fewer if you are easily offended. The humor is quite vulgar.What really surprised me was the heart and sentimentality of this really cool story. The characters are so heartwarming and easy to connect to. They are so down to earth, flawed and far from perfect - unlike in most big city romances. The characters in "Trainwreck" really grew on me. The movie's surprisingly nuanced heroine, played by Amy Schumer, goes through one hell of a development (which is rare for movies of this type). Bill Hader turns out to be surprisingly charming and appealing. The performances are absolutely hilarious, from the main to the supporting cast. "Trainwreck" unveiled John Cena and LeBron James as surprise comedic talents, and also the one that let Tilda Swinton - playing an unrecognizable, eyeliner-heavy magazine boss - snarl to Schumer's character, "I wouldn't fuck him with your dick." Those three really hit it. As Aaron's star patient and best friend, LeBron James is the secret highlight of this film, playing a version of himself who's sensitive, analytical and strangely stingy.This movie is a real and ultimately rewarding piece of work. A rom-com infused with actual human feelings (last seen in "Crazy Stupid Love") is such a rare accomplishment - but Amy Schumer and Judd Apatow did it! Wonderfully hilarious, surprisingly touching and delightfully written, this is an excellent example of romantic comedy at its best. I even liked how they used the soundtrack as a comic effect throughout the film."Trainwreck" works so well because we believed it. We believe Amy and Aaron and the people in their lives could be sitting at the next table in a restaurant.And that ending... I gotta admit it: it made my heart melt.

Boring, all over the place and just not funny. Lebron James was the best thing about the movie. The movie had no direction or point for that matter relying on shock value regurgitated from Schumer's stand up act but not well translated to film. Bill Hader and the real star of this movie Lebron James almost salvaged a pretty bland and otherwise forgettable movie except Lebron just didn't have the screen time. That's how bad this movie is it makes you want more Lebron James.

This movie has proved to me that rotten tomatoes is flawed and I am never going to use this site as a move review site but i will use this site as virtual toilet paper. Thanks Amy.
It was funny and moving

I guess everyone who is into comedy films knows the name Judd Apatow, a talented writer, producer & director. Having launched comedy giants such as Steve Carell, Seth Rogen, Jonah Hill, Michael Cera, Melissa McCarthy to the big screen, Apatow has made himself quite a unique force in the industry. This film, which is his fifth feature film directorial effort (after The 40-Year-Old Virgin, Knocked Up, Funny People, This Is 40), & also the first film he dint write. This comedy flick is written by it's star, stand-up comedian Amy Schumer (in her feature film debut). Here is my problem with films such Bridesmaids, This is 40, The Five Year Engagement or any other comedy along the lines of those. They run about for 2 hours, and almost drains me, I feel somehow the humor dries up. Nevertheless, Schumer and Apatow have crafted an almost classic date movie yet one that's fresh and a little edgy. More so the former than the latter, but most romantic comedies don't ever find an edge. There's something in here for everyone, whether you're a guy into sports or not (especially if you are into sports though) or whether you're a woman who loves chick-flicks or a hardcore feminist. Somehow, the film exists as this acceptable contradiction. I must admit, I dint know much about Amy Schumer, it was the buzz surrounding her these last few months is something which curiously interested me. After seeing her host this year's very boring MTV awards (which she was the best part off), I can imagine why people claim she is going places. Luckily for me, I really enjoyed this film! The film is original in that it reverses typical gender roles in romantic comedies where the woman is the pursuer and the man is the pursuee. The script, written by Amy Schumer, is what really puts this film over the top.When you team up Judd Apatow, one of the best comedy directors working today, with Amy Schumer, one of the best comedians working today (arguably), you've struck gold & did I mention it has Bill Hader, like who doesn't like Bill Hader? The story follows Amy (Amy Schumer) was taught, by her father (Colin Quinn) at a very young age, that true monogamy isn't possible. As an adult, she's now a successful magazine writer; that's afraid of commitment. So she constantly uses men, she meets at bars, for sex, even though she is in a relationship with Steven (John Cena). One day her boss (Tilda Swinton) assigns her a story, on a popular sports doctor named Aaron Conners (Bill Hader). After getting to know the guy, she's amazed to find out that she actually has romantic feelings for him. Her way of life is put to the test. I'm a huge Judd Apatow fan (Knocked Up is one of my all-time favorite movies) and I've really enjoyed all of his films (even Funny People which is considered his weakest). They tend to be way too long (usually close to 2 hours, or more), and they also usually contain several repetitive actor 'improve scenes', that seem to never end, but they're always hilarious and heartfelt. Apatow is amazingly skilled at combining really emotional drama, with silly slapstick comedy. This film is no different, than any of his previous work, even though he didn't write it. It seems exactly like an Apatow flick, just with a female lead instead of a male; so it's really impressive that he found a female comedian/actress/writer, that seems to think just like he does! While this film isn't the raunch-fest I expected, it still had its moments and I still enjoyed it. The two leads are both complex and have some depth to them. Amy's character is smart, funny, outgoing but can also get emotional and dark at times. The dramatic and more emotional parts revolve around the relationship between Amy's sister (Brie Larson) and her father (Colin Quinn). Their chemistry is what sold me and it all works well. Quinn also gets the chance to deliver some of the film's best one liners as well as a speech at the opening which set the tone for the rest of the film. Hader's Aaron is the normal guy among all the outrageous ness but he holds his own. The film was also able to get some great, funny performances by those who you may not expect, mostly from some well-known athletes. The film does get a little formulaic at times but it chooses to approach this in a way that is smart, real, and non-cliche in the way that it handles relationships. This is because the characters are real and that's what makes them more relate able. There were many moments in this film that made me laugh out loud including a scene with John Cena in a movie theater which I won't spoil. By now we know that with a Judd Apatow films you'll get a nice blend of raunchy humor and heart. It is a tried and true formula - and it works again here but with something different and that's Amy Schumer. Sure there might be a few uneven moments..but the duo here help create one of the funniest romantic comedies I have seen in a long time with one of the most fun finale scenes I've had the pleasure of seeing all year long. Schumer is a force here, knocking every gag out of the park but also displaying some quite impressive dramatic skills that one doesn't expect from a stand-up comedian. Bill Hader is finally given and masters the lead role he deserves perfectly. He is lovable, relate able in every way and is the perfect match for Amy on the big screen. Their chemistry here is undeniable. Brie Larson is also very good as Schumer's sister, reminding everyone the world's greatest mystery: why isn't she in more films?! However, John Cena surprises with a supporting role filled with hysterical one liners. On top of that, he has great comedic timing! Lastly, Tilda Swinton is flat out great and unrecognizable and even LeBron James manages to be quite funny. Daniel Radcliffe & Marisa Tomei have a hilarious cameo as well. Of course the film film does have some negatives, for example the film does slow down comically in the second half. Some scenes either feel out of place or don't work from the get go and it halts the pace a bit. There is a certain pair of cameos that the joke they take part in doesn't work at all. On the whole, 'Trainwreck' is a sweet, beautifully filmed, tender (and very profane) first outing for the talented Amy Schumer. The film subverts the rom-com genre because of its unlikely protagonist, Amy, a woman who doesn't look perfect and is totally likable because of that. At the same time, the film's biggest flaw is how much it adheres to the rom-com formula, but it doesn't detract from the quality overall. Judd Apatow has given us the funniest film (or maybe at par with Spy) of this year. Give it a watch!
Am I the only one who didn't think this movie was funny?

Hilarious, and touching at times. Very entertaining movie. Surprised by Lebron!
Not what I expected to be honest. Most of the "funny" bits were used in the trailers for this film. It had it's emotional moments but overall it did not have me laughing or even cracking a smil.e

The title is a misnomer; this is efficient, coherent and positive high comedy; if it intends calling the heroine a trainwreck then it's wrong again, since she is an intelligent, competent and compassionate person, even if she does get intoxicated and have innumerable partners. A film about a man in that situation would never be called Trainwreck. Amy Schumer both writes and acts very well, with accuracy and depth; her script and story have real warmth, and her character is an attractive person. The father's tale is beautifully told and heart rending; there are tears among the laughter. The sister and her family are fine touchstones. The film includes major African American sports stars in big comic roles, which they perform with the �lan that you would expect; it also takes racism to task, not just against Black people but also Asians in a short vignette; and there are enough feminist messages, even if they are centred on sexual gratification. Amy is not afraid to challenge female as well as male behaviour. For Australians, there would be ironical echoes with their fraught recent national debates about racism in sport. The film's comedy is camp and right out there. With examples like Snowpiercer and now this, Tilda Swinton is clearly a master in portraying the horribly funny, monstrous boss, possessed of a fleeting veneer of geniality. Her sinewed arm showing Amy the door is like a sword. The average male might feel that the film doesn't spare him much - he would be right about that; it is an unashamed effort at tipping the scales. Not a film for young kids, due to explicit sex scenes, language, drug use and nudity. But a thoughtful and entertaining one for grown-ups.

The chick flick gets a necessary infusion of fresh blood under Schumer's able hands as, for once, the lead is not "eccentric" or "not pretty" or "career driven" or "misunderstood" or whatever bone is usually thrown the audience as for why she is not popping out kids to beat the band: she doesn't want that. In point of fact, she is the epitome of "bad girl" in that she sleeps around and how. She's seen in many scenes on her back with her legs splayed open. Or at least that's how it begins. No worries, she sees the error of her rebel ways, but only after we enjoy the ride to her change of mind. Along the way are pretty interesting characters too, not the least of which is Colin Quinn, finally given a role the SNL alum can get his teeth into. Some basketball players fill out the roles usually reserved for the ugly secondary "friends" clich�s aptly and the boyfriend, Hader, shares nice chemistry with Schumer. But this is Schumer's ticket and she does quite well in this her first time out. What's next? Team up with Melissa McCarthy, or is that too obvious?

Amy Schumer's Trainwreck flips the gender conventions of most rom-coms with refreshing effect, yet director Judd Apatow leads it down a well-trodden and weary path of mediocrity.I like Amy Schumer. I love Bill Hader. I have come to dislike Judd Apatow. It seems a shame that the latter can have the most effect on my enjoyment of this film than the former. Trainwreck, after the half-hour mark, starts to feel like every other Apatow film; overly long, thin on gut-busting gags and more unlikable characters than fun ones. A strange combination for what is billed mainly as a comedy.Schumer's script premise is at least something different, with her central character being a 30-something sexual deviant with commitment issues - traits that are usually assigned to male leads in rom-coms. However, beyond that it is a paint-by-numbers plotline that seems to follow the genre around like a bad smell. So, it's up to the leads to distract us with some amazing gags, right?... Wrong.As much as I love Bill Hader his role is slightly subdued here and Schumer's character becomes more of a target for anger than the hero you want to succeed. Their interactions produce a few chuckles but not the belly-laughs you'd expect from such comedy talent. Instead, a host of cameo appearances steal the spotlight.Tilda Swinton is fantastic as Amy's obnoxious and aloof boss and delivers the films best one-liners. Athletes John Cena and LeBron James also steal the show by parodying the buff male stereotypes, with Cena in particular delivering the most cringe-worthy attempt at dirty talk ever committed to screen.It has its moments and can certainly be ranked toward the higher end of the scale of the genre, but there have and will be a lot funnier films out this year.
This movie is completely offensive. The language and content are horrible!

A bit off beat for a romantic comedy. While still definitely a chick flick, this one treads hard on the sexual edge and asks some interesting questions. Schumer's character is obsessive about casual sex and terrified of commitment - she objectifies men as shown in a series of casual encounters. Of course she meets the love of her life, and the movie is about the attendant problems. Colin Quinn does well playing the father, and LeBron also is credible and well-spoken. Schumer is also reasonable as a heavy-set and often not-so-attractive lead which is refreshing. Worth a trip to the theater, and has a few laughs, and in any case is ten times better than any comedy Adam Sandler or their ilk are presenting.

Trainwreck was incredibly funny, but I was surprised by how real and raw it was. Admittedly, it felt like it took a bit to find the plot, but once it got going, man, it was one hell of a ride. This movie relishes making you uncomfortable, as it should; a lot of the topics from death to how bad patterns can instill a self-destructive mindset shouldn't be treated as if a sitcom's laughtrack is supposed to play under them. The laughs that they do get are definitely of the darker variety. None of it feels forced, either, not even when the movie finds its way to those romantic comedy staples. It all comes off as natural and the types of intimate talks and fights that people actually have.The script was written by Amy Schumer herself and this could have very well come off as a Mary Sue self-insert fanficition, right down to naming her character Amy. But instead of turning herself into some perfect paragon who's awesome at everything, she writes a flawed human being who is still sympathetic even through the bad decisions she's made. This very well could be her way of working out some of her own issues and it comes out beautifully. Bill Hader also plays a lovable dork of a doctor who falls for Amy and is quite the likable character. But for me, the standout has to be Lebron James, who turns in some of the most hilarious deadpan humor of the movie. Something about the world's most famous basketball player grilling Hader's character for not visiting in Cleveland and trying to get him to pay for lunch just had me in stitches.This being a Judd Apatow film, there are of course a good share of raunchy jokes. Not all of them are laugh-out-loud funny, but the ones that are bust your gut wide open. It certainly helps that all of the actors had good chemistry and can work off of each other really well. Yet underneath all of this is an astounding amount of heart that makes you feel like you came away with something at the end of it all. I'd gladly see it again and would encourage you all to do the same.

I was expecting simply a funny if somewhat raunchy comedy but was pleasantly surprised to find a good emotional story and some solid acting as well. Schumer is excellent as is Colin Quinn as her dad. Hader & Lebron are just kind of there but have some good lines, including the repurposing of some Kanye lyrics. There are a number of people that really shine despite small parts and add to the overall comedy, including Tilda Swinton as Amy's disinterested boss, Dave Attell as Amy's homeless pal and Parks & Recreation's Jon Glaser as Amy's sketchy co-worker. John Cena was a good sport about his role and did a nice job too, even if we see quite a bit more of him than we needed to (see his first scene and you will know what I mean).

Train Wreck Review A woman who has been in a lot of relationships with other guys has met the perfect guy for her, but she is reluctant to leave her past and move out of her comfort zone. The movie Train Wreck stars comedian/actor Amy Schumer who is a huge star right now. She has a father (Collin Quin) who cheated on her mother during their marriage and they get a divorce while she and her sister are very young. It looks like Amy (Amy Schumer) is heading down the same rode but she's not married and she's not a cheater she's just been with a lot of guys.This characteristic is often given to male actors but this film is switches it up it's kind of refreshing and different in a way.  She's a writer for a magazine and kind of the artsy type of girl and not interested in sports or anything like that but she's dating a fitness trainer played by John Cena, a WWE professional wrestler in real life, and he is hilarious and might be gay, but he loves Amy, opposites attract. Anyway that doesn't work out and she freaks out and for good reason during a sex scene where he's sort of homoerotic. There is some male nudity in movie, but it's not frontal nudity. No female nudity though, kind of disappointing, but actually the love scenes are pretty hilarious and they're really not that racy. She's has to write an article about a sports Physician, Aaron played by Bill Hader who isn't really attractive, super nerdy, and a trainer to Athletes like Lebron James he's in the movie and he plays himself, and he does well actually. He's plays Aaron's best friend and client. There's some other athletes with smaller roles like NFL Football player, Tony Romo and Amare` Stoudamire who is another NBA basketball player.  Amy's sister, Kim (Brie Larson) is happily married and has children with Tom (Mike Birbiglia). So she went the opposite the way of her father. She has a great life and it doesn't look complicated on the outside as it is on the inside.  Both of these women are very attractive with great personalities, Amy's really funny, but The people around her are funnier than her. Dave Attel, another comedian plays a homeless man who is friends with Amy and their relationship is strictly platonic and hilarious he's in a few scenes but they're really funny. Amy's friend Nicky (Vanesssa Bayer who's on Saturday Night Live. She's also attractive and funny. I actually wouldn't mind seeing her in a starring role in a movie cause she very attractive to me, but that's just my opinion. SNL writer Leslie Jones is in cameo. She stars in the next Ghostsbuster movie. It's another funny scene. Matthew Broderick, is in the movie. Daniel Radcliffe and Marisa Tomei star in a movie with in a movie about walking dogs, which is really funny. It seems like I'm forgetting some people, but this movie has a lot star power going for it.  The sentimental scenes really got to me and they were very sad, Her father is dying and it's just sad it's breaks away from the film and even if it fits in. I personally didn't like them, but everything else is great.  This movie is really funny and just plain fun I enjoyed it a lot. It has a ton of stars and keeps the audience's attention really well. So I thought it was excellent and I hope to see more Amy schumer movies in the future. (9/10 on this one.)

The peak of Amy Schumer's 15 minutes. So this is about that one girl that you probably know in your own life: she dates terrible guys, she's more or less a functioning alcoholic, and she barely has her life together enough to hold down a full time job. Her life is in for a shake-up when she meets a good guy (Bill Hader). This movie has been getting a lot of traction, so of course I had to take a day off and check it out (side note: I can't believe I could get a ticket for under $5, but I suppose that's the perk to seeing a movie at 10:30 AM on a Thursday.) Given that I already knew that this is a Judd Apatow production, I can say that this is everything that I was expecting it to be, which is mostly positive. While this may be an Apatow production, this is a vehicle for Schumer herself, as she is front in center, writing and starring. She has been getting a lot attention lately, which is largely because talented female comedians are so hard to come by, especially ones that have a means of reaching both genders. The girl's got talent and comedic timing, and not only that, she's got a voice as well, not afraid to speak her mind on whatever issue she feels passionately about. This is where Trainwreck succeeds the most, and it is completely her doing. Also helping the party is the very strong supporting cast. Brie Larson has been great since Scott Pilgrim, and John Cena, like other wrestlers before him, actually does have acting abilities, and he has a number of laugh-out-loud worthy lines. Bill Hader really gets to show the full extent of his acting range, and I never saw him as the S.N.L. guy here, I saw him as a real human being. Stealing the show is LeBron James, though, and he is given tons to do; even though he wasn't happy with his performance from what I hear, the way they utilize him just flat out works. Now if you recall from the first paragraph, you may gather that I have a criticism here, which is Judd Apatow's constant folly: his movies go on for longer than they need to. It's something he's never been able to correct, and it has always been a problem. Just leveling here: there is no reason why a comedy has to be longer than 100 minutes. If you've got something working, you may be able to push it to 110, but even then, it's a risk that has rare payoff. It's like the movies he makes have all of the deleted scenes featured in it, and this runs about 15 - 20 minutes longer than it needs to. It's never as trying as Funny People which is a legit 2 1/2 hour movie, but it still stands as a mark against itself. It's still funny, though, and I enjoyed this a whole lot. This makes me happy to see this financially succeed in the same way that I was happy for Bridesmaids on behalf of Kristen Wiig: this can only mean that we are going to get more Amy Schumer projects, which is something I want to see in the future.

A film with a great cast, a tried and true romcom premise, and yet, there's something missing. Schumer is known for her edgy and often very sexual comedy, of which there is plenty of in the first half of this film. Hader is as funny as ever, and both John Cena and LeBron James give surprisingly funny performances. Then why is the plot so disappointing? Given Schumer's comedy, I went into this movie expecting a very different ending than the one we got. I thought I'd be seeing a romantic comedy that was going in a different direction, a bait-and-switch where there is no typical "happy ending," but one more in tune with Schumer's brand of comedic material. That said, it was nice to see Amy Schumer break into film acting, as her stand-up and television career have definitely ensured she deserves some time on the big screen, and I feel this film and its general success proves she can do so no problem.

from Judd Apatow, where he makes Amy Schumer (also the writer) a star with just one movie. It reverses the roles of a romantic comedy - the woman here is the one who "sleeps around" a lot, then meets the man who clicks with her and then the tropes ensue - but they commit to it and the acting is really terrific across the board. And FUNNY throughout, very funny, with people like John Cena and even more surprisingly basketball star Lebron James. I recommend it, except for one caveat: it's too long. Apatow needs an editor to tell him no, but he won't listen since he doesn't have to. Thus we get a very good movie in the style of his influences, James L Brooks and John Cassavetes once again. Though with Schumer in the lead, it's crass in the best ways and likeable too.

A fairly fresh take on the romantic comedy and worth an afternoon at the cinema! 08-08-2015

'Inside Amy Schumer' is an awesome comedy sketch show and a personal favorite, but this movie is far away from that. Starts off great, then turns into your typical 2010-onward rom-com with characters falling for each other even though they both don't want to, but then they give in, but their differences make things complicated, yadda yadda yadda.I'd really like for Judd Apatow to at least try and make a comedy UNDER TWO HOURS, take example from the 80s and 90s and make one that's an hour and a half and doesn't have a soap opera drama chapter in its final thirty minutes, which makes the total two hours of Trainwreck a chore. I also don't know why modern comedies need its main characters to be cynical self-centered bastards that treat other people like shit, with the occasional goody two-shoes character that's totally oblivious to the fact that someone's an asshole. With that type of humor, which is based on people being jerks and insulting each other, you can almost feel the grip of auto-censorship as visually vulgar gags are avoided, as are insults that are based on race, weight, physical appearance and nationality - it's just personal insults, and some slapstick here and there. One visual that's prominent in the movie is men's asses, as there are plenty of male butt-cheeks shown throughout the movie, without a single boob, side boob, nipple or female ass, and I think Schumer didn't even show her belly button, not even during sex scenes. Is that equality? What the fuck?Plenty of cameos in this one, from notable comedians you've seen on Schumer's show or on Adult Swim shows, as well as athletes such as LeBron James. Speaking of which, the best part of this movie is WWE wrestler John Cena. I'm used to booing this man, but he was the best part of this movie, and the funniest lines were delivered by him. Never give up, Cena! Anyway, once he's gone from the story, which is early in the movie, the story falls flat. I don't even feel like mentioning any details of the actual story, as anyone who has seen a couple of rom-coms over the last few years could guess the entire script. The only conclusion I can make after watching this is that John Cena should make comedies, have him team up with The Rock, with Mark Wahlberg as well, because those two could play twins. I'll forget the vast majority of Trainwreck in a couple of days.

This summer comedy is anything but a trainwreck. Judd Apatow's newest project is filled with moments for laughter, crying, and surprisingly, a very convincing performance by LeBron James. While TRAINWRECK is a very fun film to watch, it never brings anything new to the typical "rom-com", playing it safe and staying within boundaries that writer, Amy Schumer, did not break. Schumer, however, did a wonderful job playing Amy, a "trainwreck" of a woman who lives life the way her father taught her, that monogamy is unrealistic. The crazy Bill Hader never fails to impress me (see The Skeleton Twins), this time playing a non-crazy person as the leading man, Dr. Aaron Conners.
Unapologetic force of nature Amy Schumer is known for her irreverent humour, but it's her emotional honesty that shines through in "Trainwreck."

If you like brainless fun, this is a good one!

It was a matter of expectation. I went to see Trainwreck, hoping to have really good laughs and see some touching moments you often see in Judd Apatow films. If I'd known in advance that this was going to be a dramedy about the life of one of the most unsympathetic female characters in recent years, I would've given this film at least one more star. The trailer advertised a completely different film, which, in the end, resulted in me leaving the theater feeling unsatisfied and disappointed. I do love Schumer's writing style, but the role of Amy should've been played by somebody else. I didn't buy the romance between Schumer and Hader, and I was more interested in the supporting characters than the leading characters (people like Tilda Swinton and Ezra Miller deserved more screen time). The jokes are hit-and-miss for the most part, and I just don't like comedy films with pathos. Trainwreck is an unfunny and quite boring film.
