Trainwreck is not a bad movie, but it had the potential to accomplish much more than it did. Amy Schumer and Bill Hader were both fantastic. The cast was phenomenal. Most of the star-studded supporting cast could have been utilized better. John Cena was one of the exceptions; his performance completely surprised me and left my sides hurting. All in all, I feel like the opening three quarters of the movie deserved a better concluding quarter of the movie. The story began comically droll but strayed away from its initial formula and turned into another predictable rom-com. If you go into this movie with high expectations, you may leave disappointed.

Formulaic? Well, our lead character works for a magazine and has a hard-as-nails boss. The love-interest is (mostly) passive in this relationship. And there is a Black best friend.But the formula is only a frame. What makes Apatow's films unique is that the lead women in these movies don't have quirks; they have flaws. These flawed characters make them much more interesting to watch, and the more you're interested, the easier it is to laugh with them and laugh at them.Like Bridesmaids before it, Trainwreck is about a woman whose happiness and unhappiness rest squarely in her own behavior, with very little to do with outside influences. In other words, she has no one to blame but herself for whatever pain or sadness she might experience. Schumer's writing is smart, witty, and above all, self-effacing. The supporting cast is phenomenal, with Tilda Swinton, LeBron James, and John Cena (!) turning in charismatically funny roles. I wouldn't go so far as to call Bill Hader the weakest performer, but he simply isn't asked to do very much in this movie but be a nice guy. Still, his comedic talent comes into full force with his utterance of one single word: NO!

A return to form for Apatow who specializes in this brand of filthy/sweet romantic comedies that have an incredible heart, and a welcome introduction to Amy Schumer who gives a fantastic performance on screen and crafted a vulgar, insightful, and touching screenplay about a woman learning to grow up and move on past the "trainwreck" of her past. Imagine a comedy starring a sloppy, unattractive guy firmly addicted to alcohol and pot.Imagine this guy is dating a female bodybuilder. She's confident, sophisticated, cultured, intelligent, and sweet. She's even thinking of proposing-but this guy dumps her because he's a bit weirded out by the whole bodybuilder thing, and SO not ready for that kind of commitment. He's even been cheating on her, repeatedly, and doesn't apologize. We get a few is-she-a-lesbian-I-don't-know jokes in, then leave her on the curb while our main man forgets she existed.Next up, this guy visits his family. He makes fun of his niece for being interested in science at age 10, then mock his brother for marrying down.Soon, our main man meets the gal of his dreams. She's a sports doctor who treats world-famous patients and regularly headlines major magazines. She's top of her field in general medicine and surgery, and participates in medical aid initiatives in developing countries during her spare time. She's wealthy, independent, confident, kind, generous, and ready to settle down. She soon falls for our protagonist.Eventually, this guy (A) cheats on his multiple M.D. girlfriend, multiple times; (B) refuses any notion of commitment; (C) announces that he hates sports despite his girlfriend's occupation; (D) causes his girlfriend to miss a major surgery, jeopardizing her career, and refuses to apologize; and (E) is fired from his job after sexually assaulting a 16-year-old girl--though it's ok, because he didn't know she was 16, and she was "asking for it."He lounges around the house for weeks, drives drunk, and otherwise spirals out of control. Meanwhile the doctor is given a prestigious award for humanitarian aid.Now imagine that at the end of the movie, one day after crashing into a tree while drunk AND stoned, our main character resolves to fix his commitment issues and get back with his girlfriend in one stroke. He throws out all his booze, invites the doctor to an empty basketball stadium, and announces his intentions to recommit to the relationship.Imagine the doctor says yes.Imagine she allows herself back into this man's life. The man who cheats on everyone he dates, mocks little girls for liking science, drives while wasted, and smacks 16-year-olds around in the bedroom.Imagine all that, then reverse the genders and you have TRAINWRECK.
This was funny! For both guys and gals! Chick flick storyline and does take over in the second half, but the laughs.....just wow.
Loved it... didn't want to get up at all during the movie even shed a few tears... way to show some range Amy!!

To call this movie a Rom-Com is a true disservice to the film. This is a movie about a woman who happens to begin a relationship while we're watching. Her relationship with her father plays on equal footing as that of the one with Hader (whom it's nice to see in a starring role), although both take a back seat to the brilliance of Amy herself. The film has an assured feel that comes from Schumer's hand in both the writing and portrayal of her character. It's a role she clearly knows intimately. The jokes are layered with more subtly than maybe initially noticeable and delivered well-timed by every character. It is not necessarily Apatow's normal style but does feel like a progression that he seemed to aim for in Funny People and succeeded with here. I personally cannot wait for more from any of them.
7-8 scenes were both unfunny and unnecessary. This film should have been an 1 hour 20 minutes with less Colin Quinn.
Great movie! Very funny RomCom.

Okay so this is my first actual review I've ever posted of a movie. I hope to continue to do this for all the movies I go see.Trainwreck: I thoroughly enjoyed myself at this movie. I'll start by saying that the acting in this movie was outstanding and for Amy Schumer's big screen debut I cant imagine she could be much happier with it. I was a big fan of Bill Hader on SNL (for any SNL fans many cameos from season 40 cast) and it was nice to see him not only acting but, also acting very well. But I think that you have to give LeBron James, for the most part athletes are terrible actors, yet James gave the movie some much needed comedy, and banter between Hader's character. Now the surprise was that even though there were some fantastic comedy scenes there were many dramatic and slow parts that made you think about relationships, that were actually beautiful and refreshing from most *cough cough* all of the crappy RomCom's in the past 3 years. So in conclusion Trainwreck was a fun time that also makes you think about the modern world and modern relationships while also being funny. I'd say great for the parents and mature minds A.K.A. not for kids. A great night out. 4 stars.

A fine return to form for director Judd Apatow, who just happened to find the perfect comedienne for his bro-ish breed of comedy. Amy Schumer's script is nicely plotted and constantly funny, giving viewers a highly relatable tale about "getting-your-shit-together", and the cast knows how to deliver both gags and emotion. Winks at celebrity culture, bawdy sex scenes, and assured chemistry between Hader and Schumer make for a film that's everything you expected, yet so much more, and it only gets better as it goes on. Apatow's directing hasn't evolved so much in the 8 years since Knocked Up, but he's doing what he does best here, and it will make you fall in love with his crass-yet-lovable humor all over again.

I spent more time wishing I was not watching these horrible cringe worthy scenes than enjoying the movie. There were a few funny scenes, but for the most part the movie was indistinguishable from the hundreds of other romcom movies. Would have been a fine movie to watch on Netflix but I do regret spending the money to see it in theaters.
Surprisingly entertaining with good characters,

fresh off her hit comedy series Amy Schumer makes the jump to the big screen in her first film from Judd Apatowit's a fireball of a performance from Schumer playing a more comedic version of herself being an overly-sexual, detached, jokey 'trainwreck' of a personwe all know at least one of those in our lives; someone who cant commit, give things a try or be willing to care in the slightestthere's a lot of dark and heavy material here next to a chockfull of laughs that pop up every 5 minsBill Hader's great too as well as her sister played by Brie Larson who is brave enough to start living and have a familyand there's enough wacky cameos to fill up a TV sketch from Michael Cena to Tilda Swinton to even Lebron Jamesone of the funnier films to come along if not one of the finest

In my opinion the BEST movie Apatow has directed. Funnier, smarter, and better written (thanks to Schumer's brilliant script) than any of Apatow's other offerings, many of which are already fantastic movies. Brilliantly captures the behaviors, struggles, and relationship dynamics of those afraid of intimacy in a way that was believable and hilarious in ways that don't stoop to the often cliche and overused high school level of humor that many in this genre fall back on. Can't recommend this movie more. Best comedy I've seen in decades.
Have not laughed that hard since Bridesmaids. No doubt the comedy hit of the summer. Hilarious!

Manhattan journalist Amy (Schumer, who also penned the script) gets assigned a profile of a sports doctor Aaron (Hader, significantly reigned in from "SNL") and falls for him, making her question her morally dubious dating habits, while also dealing with her obnoxious editor (Tilda Swinton) and her ailing father (Colin Quinn, another SNL vet). While there are genuinely big laughs and Schumer makes a convincing jump from TV sketch comic to rom-com lead, the film almost feels like two movies battling it out at once: a raucous, ribald sex romp, and a more tepid dramedy with the standard story beats and unexpectedly serious life-and-death moments. This is understandable, since director Judd Apatow's other recent efforts seem to suffer from this kind of schizophrenia as well, but at the same time the tone varies from scene to scene and can be somewhat disorienting. Regardless, there are enough laughs to make it worth watching, even though Hader's vast comic abilities are scuttled and the feel-good climax doesn't mesh with what's come before. Not the wild comedy that the marketing campaign might have you believe, but all in all still worthwhile.

A hilarious rom com which is something sadly you don't hear everyday these days in movies. Amy Schumer gives a tour de force comedic performance balancing humor and really strong emotional material to prove she isn't a one trick variety performer, she is a movie star. Bill Hader is also excellent show more and more depth as an actor with each film he takes on. Tilda Swinton is phenomenal as Amy's boss to the point that I want a spin off movie for her character. Brie Larson is wonderful as ever as Amy's sister and Collin Quinn really shines as Amy's father. John Cena is surprisingly hilarious as is LeBron James. Ezra Miller is really funny but a tad underused as is Vanessa Bayer. I wish we got more office scenes with Bayer, Miller, and Swinton. I would even love a spin off full length version of the movie within the movie "The Dogwalker" with Daniel Radcliffe and Marisa Tomei. The script is excellent and proves Schumer's writing talents are going to be some of Hollywood's best scripts within the next few years if she continues doing them (which please please please). I didn't mind the length of the movie because I loved the characters so much and was having a great time but like every Judd Apatow film, the running time started to show and wear out its steam towards the end. This is one of the best comedies of the year so far and Amy Schumer has made her case for Hollywood's next top comedic actress.
Absolutely laughed my butt off and cried all in the same movie. I will be seeing this again for the second time in the theatre.

Amy and judd managed to do something i did not expect,ever. They made colin quinn watchable. ba-zing !. (also, btw...Tilda Swinton is actually freakin' hot with hair and make-up for a change, great actress,but I had no idea how beautiful she is,so way to go Trainwreck). It is that perfect mix of humour and chick stuff. The ladies get to see themselves and their sisters in the film, and the guys get a few raunchy jokes (although a lot tamer and sweeter than i thought it would be). It is the perfect "date movie", and I wish they had gone for a "hard-R" instead, but overall, enjoyable,some laugh out loud moments, and a definite star-making turn for the films lead actress, who, while I am already a huge fan, proved she could carry a film like it was no biggie, and that's quite a feat for a first timer right out of the gate. Recommended, but "lighter" than her show itself is.
Great delivery of lines/jokes by entire cast- first half versus second half- a tie
The worst, most unfunny, dead, garbage I have ever had the misfortune to see and listen to. Yuck.
Could have removed the Marv Albert scene and a couple of scenes tightened but still very funny. Great writing and super supporting cast. Wildly funny to all but the prudish or unsophisticated viewer.

Moments of brilliant humor - including great lines from several cameos - spoiled with too much cliche. The over-the-top distant bitchy magazine boss; the near-hapless doofus - yet brilliant doctor; a crotchy dad; a hair-trigger Amy whose personality does a 180 in no time flat. Eh. Decent summer fluff, but her comedy is usually so much tighter and funnier.
one of the funniest movies ive ever seen!!!??????????

I love Amy Schumer. I think her brand of pointed satire is brilliant. That brilliance is crystal clear in Trainwreck. This is a good movie.Let me list the big things I think are wrong with the movie and if they don't bug you, you will love this film... The most important problem that I have is the structure. I was going to say the writing, but the truth is that Amy's writing in the bits is brilliant, but she is unskilled at stringing the bits together coherently. So there are a few clunky attempts to tie things together. Another problem, I feel that it's related to Amy's lack of structural experience, is that there are wayyyy too many cameos... It's as if Amy knows a bunch of famous people who enjoy Amy's humor and wanted to be involved in any capacity... so she wrote some bits for them. It made the storytelling convoluted and less-than-focused, which made the film seem too long. It was as if the editor was forbidden to cut any of the cameos, and some of them needed to go.The Good: Outstanding performances by Collin Quinn and Brie Larson bring a true emotional depth to the film (fell deeply in love with Larson). Another "great" performance was by John Cena... I say great in quotes because the character itself is a joke, and Cena plays that joke for absolutely ever single ounce of humor one would expect... stays in-character throughout.Tilda Swinton is flawless in her role. LeBron James was acceptable as LeBron James... He made me laugh. Most of his work was with Bill Hader, whom I hate... Hader was pretty good in this movie but I have to hate him, so that's all I can say about that.Amy was *exactly* what you'd expect from Amy Schumer, so if you love her, you'll be happy. I absolutely love her "loveable loser" humanity. I love her flawed character. I cried twice during the film, once for sad humanity and once for triumphI recommend this film.
Apatow returns to Knocked Up form, and Schumer pens an honest script with a refreshing voice and likeable performances. The third act is familiarly sentimental, yet the film is very, very funny.
Such a funny movie keeps u entertained the whole time! Amy shummer's year consistently putting out funny shit!

Review by Jesse Burleson of VIEWS ON FILMOK. So I've made some observations about 2015's Trainwreck (my latest review). Note to the movie itself: Bravo on the most dead-on walk of shame sequence to ever grace the silver screen. Note to LeBron James and John Cena: You guys are the top tier in your sport (NBA basketball and WWE wrestling respectively) but your acting still needs a little work. John, I'm not sure if it's the dialogue you've been saddled with or your improvised line delivery, but you come off as unfunny while everything you say seems relatively cogent. Note to Amar'e Stoudemire: You aren't really an actor either but your cameo in "Wreck" (with hardly any lines) outshines James and Cena profusely. I'm not saying you're Lawrence Olivier but keep up the good work. Note to the New York Knicks organization: Just because you are talked up in this flick doesn't mean we as an audience, don't know that your team is still kind of in the crapper. Finally, note to director Judd Apatow: We know you like the concept of raunchiness (you speak of it in interviews) but you need to hire a screenwriter who doesn't let said raunchy scenes get out of control while dragging on too long. People don't interact with a vulgar nature in every adult situation (especially during weddings, baby showers, and professional business meetings) and believable sex scenes don't involve one party being fully clothed. Now granted, Trainwreck is your latest release, it's gonna make a lot of money (I could tell from an opening day screening), and I give you credit for turning virtual unknowns into leading men and woman (Steve Carell, Seth Rogen, and currently, Amy Schumer). For me though, this is a mixed bag. And I shed a tear knowing that it could have been so much better.Now as a vehicle, Trainwreck involves a thirty-year old woman who sleeps around until finally finding the man of her dreams. In the cannon of Apatow's filmography, it's a step below 2007's Knocked Up and 2012's This Is 40 (both of these films were funnier, seemed like they had more of a script, and didn't strain for comic transgression). "Wreck" is more on par with The 40-Year-Old Virgin, an exercise that doesn't equal a movie so much as a series of drawn-out, earthy scenes. Yeah its story is more coherent but it's improv to the max and overlong (an Apatow affidavit). As for the courtship between its characters being Schumer's Amy and Bill Hader's Aaron Conners (a big time sports doctor and said dream guy), well it's simply not believable. These people are polar opposites and there's no evidence to say that they could ever function as a couple (despite giving them a two hour running time to prove it). (Spoiler Alert) oh and did I mention the ending? Well it's faintly predictable (you just knew these crazy kids would end up together). To my dismay though, I was surprised by how unique it was (just think cheerleaders dancing at Madison Square Garden). All of this in the end, doesn't negate Apatow from being Apatow. He would rather have his cast members talking like perverted sheep than showing some unadulterated emotion. He likes everything ostentatious but I wish he would just grow up.In conclusion, I was surprised by how deep Trainwreck tried to project itself (don't let the trailer fool you). This is not necessarily a comedy (especially towards the second and third act). It deals with depression, death in the family, drug use, and of course, promiscuity (which actually just occurs in the first half-hour or so). For what it's worth, Amy Schumer is the best thing going for it. Her character is real, multilayered, and has issues. Her performance here deserves a better movie, one with an actual script and not ad libs. As an actress, she's likable, strangely attractive, and backed up with some good supporting work (Brie Larson as Amy's sister, acts with her eyes, and as usual, is solid). However, this numbing movie is indeed, a "trainwreck". Apatow like in Knocked Up (remember the scene a la a baby coming out of the womb), wants to gross you out with close-ups of someone getting stitches and a flask knee getting operating on graphically (to the Billy Joel jam, "Uptown Girl"). He's the frat boy version of John Waters, a real jester.Of note: Trainwreck didn't pulverize me with its negligible, comedic vibe but I chuckled threefold. You have Amy Schumer's narration which is unconventional in a sense yet totally humorous. There's also a cameo-laden sequence involving Matthew Broderick, Chris Evert, and Marv Albert. It had to do with some sort of intervention (Evert says the word c**kblocker, I'm not kidding). Finally, look for a scene where Aims walks on a treadmill and has her body type plastered via a large computer screen. It's crazy sexy cool and sort of reinvents the whole "Hitler" strut (I felt squeamish but still laughed nervously).
Really, what was this film about. I was waiting for a story once I memorized all the vulgarities that are only funny for so long. Really bad film making. sorry.

Apatow's Trainwreck doesn't hit it out of the park like Fieg's Bridesmaids did in 2011, but it is much better than your usual rom-com fare. Looking forward to seeing Amy Schumer on the big screen again. CDW
Hilariously funny! Loved the movie and love Amy Schumer.

Trainwreck was directed by Judd Apatow and that alone stands for = Good Movie. The other aspect that made this a good movie was that Amy Schumer was hilarious and the situations and lines delivered in the film were great. It was raunchy, sweet, touching and combined the perfect amount of funny with a heart felt story. There was a slew of athletes and other fairly well known actors in the film so there was always a little surprise around every corner. Most Apatow movies have sentimental moments but Trainwreck I would argue is the biggest tearjerker yet. The connection between the 2 main characters was great and that bond really shined through all the way up to the final, rather amazing scene. If you want to laugh at a raunchy comedy you can't go wrong with this one, but if you also want a touching love story don't pass this over at the theatre.

More a traditional rom-com than I expected, but very well done. Not Bridesmaids funny, but good movie overall. Amy's acting better than expected. Worth the trip to the theater, but would also be a great rental.
We were so disappointed in this movie. All of the funny parts (with the exception of the end) were shown in the trailers.
Couldn't help myself -- I laughed so hard I almost fainted.

Pardon me for not jumping on the Amy Schumer bandwagon, but she is one more example of a supposedly "daring" comedian who is actually quite status quo and mainstream. The perfect complement to director Judd Apatow who litters his tales with dirty words and sex but is actually as innocuous as a Kate Hudson rom-com from the last decade. In fact, I would argue that BRIDE WARS has a more cutting and daring message to deliver than TRAINWRECK or any of Schumer's or Apatow's work. Pile on to that, TRAINWRECK is simply too long, lethargic, and just not very funny. And perhaps worse than anything, poor Brie Larson, who is quite the actress, is here relegated to playing the sister/homemaker with no bite or attitude. TRAINWRECK just made me feel sad in an unintentional bad way.
Writer and lead Amy Schumer proves herself a bonafide star in this hilarious, well-rounded, and uncommonly measured take on the romantic comedy.
Feels like an overlong comedy sketch with some quality laughs among several dead air and awkward moments.

Train Wreck is a movie directed by Judd Apatow and stars Amy Schumer, Bill Halder, Brie Larson, and John Cena and is written by Amy Schumer.This movie follows around a sex crazy,commitment fearing girl, Amy (Amy Schumer), as she receives an assignment from her boss (Tilda Swinton), to cover a sports doctor, Aaron(Bill Halder), who as a surprise to no one, falls head over heels in love with her.This set up has been done numerous times before with a variety and degree of success. I usually don't do this in my reviews but I want to address the negatives first because i only had one problem with the movie. That one problem, that Train Wreck's final act was much less bold and entertaining as the first two. The final act ends the movie on a high but extremely predictable note which sucks because this is one of my favorite comedies of the year and i was hoping to give it an A+.Now on to the positives. Amy Schumer! Amy Schumer! Amy Schumer! She is brilliant in every which way in this movie. As a writer she made the script a perfect about of sharp, lethal and above all hilarious humor and enough dramatic depth to stay afloat. This script foxed me with a twist I saw coming from the beginning but was done with such fineness that made it so sudden when it happened. Amy Schumer excels in her portrayal as Amy, the sex crazy, commitment fearing girl she was raised to be. This top notch performance is matched by Bill Halder's Aaron, sports doctor, with often times hilarious results.Train wreck boasts enough top notch dark and light comedy to please a wide audience and I strongly recommend seeing this movie. Train Wreck gets a A- or an 8/10.

Many short comedy sketches by Amy Schumer inserted to a full length movie script. Vulgar, understated, ridiculous, sarcastic, ingenious fun.4.5 starsI confess I look at critic ratings prior to seeing movies, expecially ones that aren't out yet. I saw Trainwreck garnered high 90 percents from the critics on Rotten Tomatoes which really surprised me so I was interested. The cover looks like Bridesmaids and the Hangover had a baby and that's somewhat accurate. What I didn't know going in was that the protagonist has starred in her own Comedy Central show for two years. In fact, she's been on Ellen and spurred viral footage of her riffing and making Ellen snort she's so funny. I think it would help for people to know she is an established comedy commodity with a distinctive vulgar and often understated style. Without that knowledge, one could make the mistake of thinking it's just another sex and puke comedy dangled before primal eyes.Maybe that alone will work for most viewers. We've been so inundated with gross films in the last 20 years for which audiences show their love through ticket sales. As for me, I think if I didn't know of Miss Schumer's notoriety and idiosyncratic style, I might has scoffed through most the movie. As is was, I enjoyed watching her brand of humor for a couple hours. Speaking of hours, there were some scenes about 3/4 of the way through when she and her boyfroend, Bill Hader, start fighting like a married couple where the film truly dragged for me. It's for those scenes as well as unnecessary penetration scenes that didn't add to the comedic lines for me. In other words, the writers didn't have to stoop that low to relate with the audience. That a; having been said, I found this film a hoot to be sure. My wife and I were in tears during the sex scene with John Cena. He's the perfect hunk to demonstrate what talking dirty is not.

Trainwreck is a pretty good comedy film but it's not as great as everyone says it is. Some people believe it's the funniest film of all time and some think it's the best comedy of this decade so far but I would have to disagree with them. The film is funny but it's not gut busting laughing. The laughs are more of a chuckle. The acting is great everyone played their part very well. Amy Schumer wrote this film and I think she did a great job for writing this film. The chemistry between her and Bill Hader is great. Also this is probably Judd Apatow's best film since 40 Year Old Virgin. The film is more of a chick flick but there are some chick flicks that I thought were funnier than this film like Bridesmaids. Also this could be a great date film for couples. I do find this film way overhyped and probably one of the most overrated films so far this year. Overall if your a fan of Amy Schumer or Judd Apatow then you'll enjoy this film.
Amy Schumer becomes a mainstream movie star in this raunchy comedy; the only thing that works against it is its overlength.
Amy at her best!! Laugh out loud funny. Loved it.
A little disappointed. More raunch than clever humor.

The story line was a little uneven and could use some editing, but it is a bravo first movie from Amy. I can't wait to see more. I will just have to be content to view her old tv shows from the beginning. Love her!
